reference.title: Bat guano
reference.shortdesc: This describes the uses and chemical nature of bat droppings.

refbody.section:
Bat guano, also called bat droppings (2-year old children may have another word for it, and 17-year old youths certainly do!), is a wonderful source of fertilizer for your garden.
Bat guano, when dried and collected, is a rich source of nitrogen. You can also spread it on yourself for use as a mosquito repellent.
Prime guano is approximately 10% nitrogen, 3% phosphorus, and 1% potassium. It is ideal for houseplants, vegetables, fruit trees, flowers, lawns, and ornamentals. For applying it, you can make a manure tea (2-6 Tbs./gal. of water), foliage feed, and a composting and soil mix.
Our company also sells a bat guano spreader, see our web page for ordering information . The BooleDozer can be used to push the bat guano into a proper BoolesEye storage facility.
